results.title: Wolf [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Janet Hines, Bin Li and Andrew Duval
results.brief_description: A woman living somewhere in the Australian high plains tends to her horses and gardens while something out of sight lurks. The woman has fantasies about a stranger who she desires to be with but also fears to be with and the line between fantasy and reality merge as she encounters the stranger in her house. This is a beautifully filmed short film that echoes the tale of “Little Red Riding Hood”. (Awards: Winner, Silver Award for Cinematography in a Short Film, NSW Australian Cinematographers Society Awards, Sydney, 1998)
results.creator_credit_for_label: AFTRS, Janet Hines, Bin Li and Andrew Duval

results.title: Wolf
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Douglas Wick and Mike Nichols
results.brief_description: Publisher Will Randall - recently retrenched and replaced by younger, sycophant protegee Stewart (James Spader) - notices strange behaviour after a wolf at full moon bites him. The behaviour involves a heightening of the senses and rejuvinates his lagging demeanor, turning him into a younger version of himself. The metamorphosis reaches full flight at the next half moon when he takes a moonlit wander and awakes in the morning covered in blood and unaware of his actions. Medical science is unable to find an answer to his symptoms, however Dr Vijay Alezias (Om Puri) tells Will he is assuming the characteristics of a werewolf, the crucial point being that Randall can only change if he already possesses the animal instinct. He finds a sympathetic ear to his predicament from his former employer’s beautiful young daughter Laura (Michelle Pfeiffer), whom he is entrusted with protecting after Stewart joins him as a werewolf but doesn’t have the love of a good woman to quell his animal appetite. A hirsute love story, part comedy, part horror, the cast also includes Christopher Plummer, Prunella Scales, Kate Nelligan and David Hyde Pierce and features an impressive gothic mise-en-scene and evocation of the New York publishing scene.

results.title: Wm Bligh
results.creator_credit: John Croyston, Alan Burke, ABC and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behind the Legend”.
Presents a dramatized re-enactment of the events surrounding the arrest of Governor William Bligh by the New South Wales Corps in 1808. Various witnesses present their accounts of cowardice and misappropriation by Bligh. Introduced by Manning Clark and written by Thomas Keneally. Cast includes Brian James as Bligh, Peter Gwynne, Richard Meikle, Kevin Leslie, John Trenaman, Robyn Nevin.

results.title: Wizard
results.brief_description: An animated fairy tale about a small-town wizard who misapplies his magical powers by casting spells on his neighbours. After being rejected by the townspeople the wizard learns that by channeling his imagination to creative ends, he can be both fulfilled and admired.

results.title: Wizard
results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of a book by Jack Kent in which an unhappy mouse consults a wizard about a potion to change him into something else. He manages to give the mouse just the right potion. With the help of this magic formula the mouse comes to appreciate his own qualities.

results.title: Wives and daughters
results.creator_credit: BBC, Sue Birtwistle and Nicholas Renton
results.brief_description: A 19th century soap opera of splendid proportions. A story of a father remarrying for the sake of his daughter. The complications begin. A new step mother, a step sister and a selfish governess, the story unfolds. Elizabeth Gaskells unfinished novel adapted to a satisfying and beautiful series. Cast includes Michael Gambon, Francesa Annis and Ian Carmichael.

results.title: Wives' tales
results.creator_credit: Claire Forster and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
280 families were affected by the deployment of the 7th and 8th battalion with INTERFET (UN Sanctioned International Force in East Timor). For the women and families left behind, there was a pressing need for group support. Shying away from a tag such as “the army wives club,” Patti-Jane Gould established the P.I.T. crew - Partners In Timor. The women of this support network speak candidly of the impact their partners departure has had on them and their children, how it feels to say goodbye, their fears, and how they adjust when life returns to “normal.” Army personnel share their fears and thoughts too and how their lives have changed since Timor. Finally, we share an emotional reunion on the docks. Introduced by Lieutenant General Peter Cosgrove.

results.title: Wittgenstein Tractatus

results.title: Wittgenstein
results.creator_credit: Bandung Prod, Channel 4 Television, BFI, Tariq Ali and Derek Jarman
results.brief_description: Ludwig Wittgenstein was born in Vienna in 1889 and he was to develop some of the most important twentieth century work on the philosophy of language and meaning. Jarman’s experimental biography is highly theatrical, interspersing biography, soliliquies, lavish fantasy and dream sequences. The film traces Wittgenstein’s life through World War I; his career as a school-teacher and eventually as an academic at Cambridge University; to his final abandonment of classical philosophy and the development of a challenging deconstruction of language which was to bring him in conflict with more positivist philosophies. Scripted by renowned English academic, Prof. Terry Eagleton, the film revolves around a series of arguments and discussions between Wittgenstein, Betrand Russell and their academic peers. This intelligent film links abstract discourse to the politics of everyday life. In the long run, Wittgenstein’s break with the hierarchy at Cambridge is not only a product of intellectual speculation but rooted in his problematic and alienated homosexuality which could not find direct expression in the higly austere and conventional environment of “high academia”. Though this film demands rigorous attention it is also a highly stylised and beautiful exercise in the possibilities of experimental cinema. With Tilda Swinton.
